metadata.name: Trasiedoc #238
metadata.description:
Behind every generative art project is a code. This code is sometimes a masterpiece but most viewers do not see it.

With the Trasiedoc project I wanted to highlight the hidden face of generative art, the code, by literally integrating the code of my biggest project to date (Dencity) in each output of the Trasiedoc project.

Margins can be hidden by pressing "x" in live mode (and optionally press "p" to see if anything happens).

Made with ❤️, code, code and p5js.

metadata.name: CENTURY-XXX-METAFRANKE #608
metadata.description:
1 of 5 in CENTURY-XXX, Series 2
Edition of 1000

Tribute to Herbert W. Franke
“In Honor of the Dinosaur of Computer Art” 

Herbert W. Franke, a pioneer of computer art, passed away on July 16, 2022 at the age of 95. CENTURY-XXX-METAFRANKE is an homage to Franke’s MONDRIAN software developed for the Texas Instruments TI 99/4 home computer in 1979, and it’s a fundraiser to digitize his archive:

“Our goal is to raise 20,000 Euro so that ZKM Karlsruhe can digitize Herbert W. Franke’s 1,800 manuscripts and make them publicly available. If we raise more money, it will be donated to the Rütgers Foundation which supports children and young adults in Africa so that they can get access to and work with technology.” 

Each frame, a single “pixel” is added to the CENTURY-XXX-METAFRANKE image. When the software first loads, 100,000 frames are run in the background to start things off. Keep it running for hours or days to see it transform entirely — it’s an “infinite animation.”

metadata.name: Ephemera #100
metadata.description:
Reflecting on fleeting things. A study of light, wildflowers, and wind.

This project is best viewed using Chrome on a computer with a modern GPU.

A special thanks to the creators of p5.js and color.js whose excellent tools helped make this project possible.

metadata.name: Mosaic #273
metadata.description:
---
Notes:
- Click to pause/unpause
- The aspect ratio is fixed 1:1 because of the way the grid and movements are generated to make sure they're the same on all screens. 
---
Description:
An 80X80 grid of tiles are scrambled, shuffled, shifted, streamed, transported,
conveyed, moved, deposited. 

There are 15 initial tile states and 5 color palettes. A set of 12 unique motion patterns
are generated for each piece. 
---
Acknowledgements:
This piece is inspired by Kim Asendorf, whose pixel-level algorithms I'm
transfixed by, and Ksawery Komputery, whose algorithmic tile-works I'm crazy
about. 
---
Made by Sam Tsao (@sam___tsao) with P5.js 
December 2021, Germany

metadata.name: ZOOM (4hwf) #39
metadata.description:
"Das System lässt keine Überraschung zu. Überraschung ist Ausdruck partieller Unkenntnis. Überraschung weist auf Mangel von Wissen hin, deutet Leerstellen an. Bisher hatten sie keine Leerstellen festgestellt." — Herbert W. Franke

ZOOM explores linear scaling of pixels by zooming into a noisy framebuffer. Various zoom levels are composed one below the other, becoming a cinematic animation through iteration of the hue values of the pixels in the framebuffer.

In Gedenken an Herbert W. Franke
Kim Asendorf, 2022

metadata.name: Separation in the Night #90
metadata.description:
For this project I was strongly inspired by the paintings of Mark Rothko, Jackson Pollock, Kazemir Malevich, but mostly token refers to the works of one of the largest figures of the European avant-garde, Paul Klee. I wanted to convey that complex color mood and atmosphere that artist achieved with oil paints. 
I have been working with color palettes and functions for a long time to make complex transitions and gradients. This code has really huge potential for a wide diversity of artworks and I would like to see as many interesting variations as possible. Enjoy<3

Project contains:

•three canvas types : horizontal, vertical, square
•rare features : vertical stripes, posterization
•press "p" to pause animation and play again
•open in tab and press "s" to save .png


Made in P5.js by @Georginerous

metadata.name: chorégraphie #296
metadata.description:
… divided in two,
like the parent in sound and motion.
yet not exactly the same, I get …


chorégraphie explores the algorithmic characteristics of recursion in audiovisual form.

The algorithm performs a recursive split. At each split stage, space is divided into four different sized quadrants. Each split stage will eventually spawn an oscillator or a synthesizer representing the current properties of recursion in sound. The process is recursively repeated until a maximum recursion depth is reached or an early return condition is met.
Additionally, an initial motion funnction is randomly selected and propageted through the recursion, so that each recursive split stage with move depending on it’s split properties in combination with time.

Click into the piece to start the audio. Each piece can be seeded with a new initial configuration by pressing the ‘s’ key.

© 2022 — Guido Schmidt

Created with:
p5, tone, @thi.ng/color, random

metadata.name: just one long day #209
metadata.description: It's just a very long day. 365 revolutions around the sun, 8,760 hours and thousands of unfamiliar eyes waiting for the next morning. What does it mean to be stuck in one day? When everything around you is changing, living, breathing, dying, only you alone, like a stone statue. Nothing can touch you, and your feelings are externally muted to a minimum. Calm, joy, fear, anxiety, despair. You don't seem to have lost the ability to live, but you are somehow helpless and immobile. All your thoughts and experiences flow through your empty body, driving you insane. Everything around you distorts and changes in your eyes. And all you can do is remind yourself that it's just one long day. And I hope your tomorrow comes very soon.

metadata.name: THE SADDEST PEOPLE !ALIVE #394
metadata.description:
Generative NFT by Andre Fuchs & The Saddest Guy Alive
2022, https://DesignerWhoCodes.de & https://TheSaddestGuyAlive.com

metadata.name: Solace #11
metadata.description:
Solace is an algorithm that generates artworks of sand dunes. It draws hundreds of thousands of tiny points according to a probability distribution calculated from the positions of the dunes.

The logic to divide the dunes into light and dark sides is simple, but produces some interesting chaotic behaviour. These are details that weren't hard-coded but emerge organically, such as the patterns on the spines of the dunes or the stripes around their bases.

Please note that the algorithm can take some time to run, especially when the number of dunes is high.

Created by lunarean.

metadata.name: Choices & Tradeoffs #61
metadata.description:
Our entire life is a series of choices and tradeoffs.

Every day we make them - insignificant routine ones, or important life-changing ones. And every time we choose something - we automatically make a tradeoff, by definition. These concepts are heavily tied together. We reap the benefits of one decision, only to be throwing away all the others. But, which one are you supposed to pick? Well, that’s for each person to figure out by themselves.

There are no right or wrong choices. Just consequences.


Made with pure JS
